greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Smallest prime followed by three gaps that are multiples of 2n.
comment: Equivalently, smallest prime such that the next three primes are at distances divisible by 2n. The gaps are generally not the same, so these are not starting points of four consecutive primes in arithmetic progression (CPAP-4) as listed in A054800. - _M. F. Hasler_, Nov 06 2018
link: OEIS index entries related to gaps between primes.
example: a(1) = 3 is the smallest prime such that the next three gaps (2, 2 and 4; involving primes 5, 7 and 11) are multiples of 2*1 = 2.
a(1) = 199 is the smallest prime such that the next three gaps (12, 12 and 4; to primes 211, 223, and 227) are multiples of 2*2 = 4.
results.author: _Jeff Burch_, Apr 20 2000
ext: More terms from Larry Reeves (larryr(AT)acm.org), Nov 09 2000
